awd_titl_txt: Quark Matter and its Role in the Evolution of Proton-Neutron Stars to Neutron Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
Galaxies are filled with hundreds of millions of compact stellar objects known as neutron stars.  Neutron stars are more massive than our Sun, but are typically only about 20 kilometers across. A thimble full of neutron star matter thus has a mass of one billion tons. At such extraordinary conditions, atomic nuclei collapse and neutrons and protons are squeezed so tightly together that even their building blocks (quarks) may be released.  The aim of this project is to study the role of quarks for newly formed neutron stars and to identify possible signatures in astrophysical observables. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in areas of physics that are richly interdisciplinary and enrich their educational experience beyond what they learn in the classroom. Students from local middle and high schools will benefit from the PI's research in the form of public lectures and multimedia presentations. This research will support the physics program at state-of-the-art astrophysical instruments, such as FAST, skA, ATHENA, and NICER, that promise the discovery of tens of thousands of new neutron stars at different stages of their evolution.

The principal aim of this proposal is to study quark matter under conditions characteristic to proto-neutron stars, using the non-local 3-flavor Polyakov-Nambu-Jona-Lasinio (n3PNJL) model to describe hot and dense quark matter, and to explore the role of quark matter in the evolution of proto-neutron stars to neutron stars. The n3PNJL model is an effective model of quantum chromodynamics that allows for a state-of-the-art modeling of quark matter.  The model accounts for the dynamical breaking of chiral symmetry and mimics quark confinement via the Polyakov-loop potential. It provides a versatile and numerically-treatable approach to quantum chromodynamics. The best available data from heavy-ion collisions and neutron star observations will be used to constrain the equation of state of (proto-) neutron star matter, which will be computed and made publicly available online at CompOSE and StellarCollapse.  Already existing, fully general relativistic numerical 2D rotation and 2D cooling codes will be used to study the rotational evolution of hot proto-neutron stars to cold catalyzed neutron stars self-consistently. Both uniformly-rotating as well as differentially-rotating systems will be considered and their role as possible sources of gravitational radiation explored.

por.por_cntn:
This research project focused on the theoretical study of the properties of ultra-hot and ultra-dense matter (superdense matter for short), which is many times denser than atomic nuclei and ten thousand times hotter than the matter in the core of our Sun. Superdense matter exists permanently deep in the cores of compact stars, so-called neutron stars, is produced during the collapse of massive stars (supernovae) and plays a key role in gamma-ray burst events, to name just a few examples. 

On Earth, the properties of superdense matter are studied experimentally with instruments such as the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider RHIC at Brookhaven and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN. On the other hand, a huge number of neutron stars exist in the universe, and their properties are being studied with instruments for sky surveys that have become operational in recent years, such as FAST, eROSITA, NICER and the gravitational-wave detectors LIGO, VIRGO, KAGRA. These instruments offer researchers unprecedented insight into the behavior of superdense matter, complementing the capabilities of terrestrial accelerators. 

Neutron stars are more massive than the Sun but are only city-sized and usually have a diameter of only about 25 kilometers. Many of them spin rapidly, often at many hundreds of revolutions per second. A thimbleful of neutron star matter would have a mass of a billion tons! Under such extraordinary conditions, atomic nuclei are squeezed so tightly together that they disintegrate. Moreover, there is an interesting possibility that even protons and neutrons are no longer stable particles but decay into their building blocks-the quarks- creating a new state of matter known as quark matter. These intriguing properties make neutron stars excellent astrophysical laboratories for studying superdense matter, its building blocks and their interactions, and even the structure of spacetime itself. In a broader sense, research on neutron stars therefore plays an important interdisciplinary role in understanding the structure and evolution of our Universe.

In our galaxy there exist hundreds of millions of neutron stars, and it has been estimated that tens of thousands of them will be observed with the next generation of radio (e.g., FAST, SkA) and X-ray (e.g., eROSITA, ATHENA) telescopes. Many of those neutron stars are in binary systems. As these neutron stars spiral together and ultimately collide with each other, they emit a burst of gravitational waves. Such waves have been detected for the very first time ever in 2017, by the U.S. based Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) and the Europe-based Virgo detector. Aside from gravitational waves, observational data are also accumulating rapidly from both orbiting and ground based observatories, spanning the spectrum from X-ray to radio wavelengths. Of particular interest is the Neutron Star Interior Composition Explorer (NICER) mission, which is dedicated to the study of extraordinary gravitational, electromagnetic, and nuclear-physics environments embodied by neutron stars. Interpreting and understanding the huge amount of data expected from all these instruments requires careful numerical analysis performed with state-of-the-art numerical codes. 

Under this NSF project, numerical codes have been developed that solve Einstein's field equations of general relativity as well as the field equations of superdense matter. The best available experimental data were used as input to set the parameters of the dense-matter theories. The codes have been rigorously checked for correctness and are available to the PI, his collaborators, and students at San Diego State University to work on research topics fundamental to our understanding of astrophysical processes related to compact stars. These range from the study of the birth and evolution of compact stellar objects-white dwarfs and (proto-) neutron stars-to their demise in stellar mergers, where compact stars collide and form new classes of massive objects.

Three undergraduate students, 5 MSc students, and 1 PhD student were funded through this research project. They received intensive training in several areas of physics (nuclear and particle physics, condensed matter theory, advanced quantum physics, general relativity),

The main results of the conducted research include the following:

1. Very high temperatures of proto-neutron stars (100 trillion degrees) have a dramatic influence on their composition. Protons and neutrons are replaced by more massive particles (so-called barons) and possibly even quarks.

2. The super strong magnetic fields of neutron stars lead to a deformation of such objects, which has hardly been considered in numerical simulations of such objects so far.

3. The mass of the super-fast rotating white dwarf CTCV J2056-3014 has been determined by fully general relativistic numerical simulations of rapidly spinning compact objects.

4. The gravitational-wave event GW190814 is most likely due to the merger of 2 black holes and not to the participation of a neutron star. 

5. The standard stability criterion of compact stars does not apply to objects containing quark matter. This could lead to the possible existence of a new class of stellar objects, which are accessible to observation.
